ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Umer, Floeano is at EPFL, a University in Switzerland.  He works in the autonomous systems lab: http://asl.epfl.ch/ Nolfi I think is at a University in

Hi Umer,

Floeano is at EPFL, a University in Switzerland.  He works in the 
autonomous systems lab:

http://asl.epfl.ch/

Nolfi I think is at a University in Italy.  I belive Floreano used 
to be at the same place.  I spoke to Floreano a bit about roving 
eyes when we were at GECCO.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Umer Iqbal" <umeriqbal81@h...> wrote:
> 
> 
> Where does Floreano work btw?
> Is he still connected with any research groups in any 
universities? or does he just work for a commercial research lab?
> 
> And does someone have info about Nolfi as well? The guy who did a 
lot of research with Floreano. He was the co-author of "Evolutionary 
Robotics" book as well if I remember correctly..
> 
> Regards,
> Umer..
> 
> 
>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: Kenneth Stanley 
>   To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Wednesday, July 07, 2004 4:42 AM
>   Subject: [neat] Re: GECCO Recap
> 
> 
>   There's definitely a variety of stuff going on at GECCO and most 
of 
>   it doesn't have to do with ANN's directly, but there were a few 
>   papers on evolving an ANN to do something.  But they were mostly 
>   very uninteresting experiments, such as classification.  I think 
the 
>   most interesting neuroevolution outside of NEAT is coming from 
>   Floreano and his group, who do evolutionary robotics using 
>   neuroevolution.  Our own group from UT also had several 
>   presentations, including one by Faustino Gomez on transferring 
>   neuroevolved controllers to the real world.
> 
>   It's true that half of GECCO is Genetic Programming.  That's 
>   becausee GECCO is a combination of the old GA and GP 
conferences, 
>   which used to be separate.  GP is kind of strange in that it's 
just 
>   one method yet it is treated like a whole area.  This 
distinction 
>   between GA and GP may be fading though over the long term as 
>   indirect encoding becomes more prominent.
> 
>   In fact, attention to indirect encoding was the big thing I 
noticed 
>   changing at this conference.  For the first time since I started 
>   attending 4 years ago, it got a lot of attention and communities 
are 
>   starting to form.  People seem to have suddenly taken notice 
that 
>   it's going to be a big deal.
> 
>   Coevolution is also getting a lot of attention, but mostly at a 
more 
>   theoretical level than practical.  Still, there was interesting 
work 
>   on cooperative and competitive coevolution, which are definitely 
>   both relevant to neuroevolution, and most of the leaders in this 
>   area go to GECCO.
> 
>   ken
> 
> 
> 
>   --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
>   > On Tue, 06 Jul 2004 21:04:55 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
>   wrote:
>   > > Did you discover any new NEAT or NEAT like research going on 
or 
>   any
>   > > interesting commercial connections?
>   > 
>   > Not really.
>   > 
>   > I attended a "Genetic Algorithms in Industry" tutorial, which 
>   actually
>   > turned out to be two guys from Dow Chemical, so it was 
>   really "Genetic
>   > Algorithms in the Chemical Industry".  They spoke in very 
vague 
>   terms
>   > for the first half hour, and when they finally put some data 
up on 
>   the
>   > slides, when someone asked what they were representing, they 
>   mumbled
>   > something about how they couldn't say what the graphs actually 
>   showed
>   > because it was proprietary.
>   > 
>   > GECCO is apparently a fusion of different conferences, and it 
>   seemed
>   > to me that many more of the papers and workshops/tutorials 
were 
>   geared
>   > more toward Genetic Programming than any other use of GAs.
>   > 
>   > There was an interesting presentation in my LBP session by a 
guy 
>   from
>   > a company that had successfully used GP techniques to identify
>   > unexploded ordnance in military artillery ranges that were to 
be
>   > converted to civilian use.  I spoke to another guy from 
somewhere
>   > called Aerospace Corp who said he was skeptical of ANNs and 
mostly
>   > looking for GP-based approaches to analyzing aerial and 
satellite
>   > photography.  It seems to me that ANN-based approaches to 
these 
>   sorts
>   > of fuzzy recognition problems would be more promising than GP
>   > approaches...so if anything I got a lot of ideas about 
potential
>   > commercial connections, if anything.
>   > 
>   > Maybe Ken or Joseph had different experiences, though.
>   > 
>   > Derek
>
